Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ship-based Science Technical Support in the Arctic 2011
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests support to augment the marine research technical services provided by the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) on their icebreakers for research cruises in the arctic region. This proposal is a collaborative between the Shipboard Technical Support (STS) department at Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) and the Marine Technician Group (MTG) at Oregon State University (OSU) to provide the highest level of shipboard technical support possible. The proposal will use a model for arctic shipboard technical support that follows best practices of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) fleet. An Arctic Cruise Coordinator will be recruited with the exclusive responsibility for creating and overseeing a precruise planning process based on existing SIO and OSU methods, modified to suit the needs of scientists sailing on the USCG cutters in the arctic. The Coordinator will work with all parties to develop efficient staffing and equipment assignments customized for each cruise leg, and develop an annual technical support budget (under the supervision of the STS manager) that will be submitted to NSF. If the requirements for an Arctic cruise cannot be met using the available resources of SIO and OSU, then the Coordinator will solicit marine technical support from other UNOLS institutions. Education and training of students, new technicians and USCG personnel in use of technology and techniques at sea is part of the broader impacts of this proposal, thus broadening the technical knowledge base that supports U.S. oceanographic research. SIO will support the acquisition and appropriate handling of underway shipboard data in concert with national data centers such as the NSF-supported R2R program, making data available to the academic community and the public at large. SIO and OSU will coordinate with NSF, USCG and the Arctic Icebreaker Coordinating Committee to define priorities for maintenance and upgrades to science equipment onboard.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2015 Cruise Outcomes:


USCG HEALY:

 -HLY_Shakedown/ Seattle to Seattle (Support for shipboard underway instrumentation, CTD, ADCP, Echosounders, XBT, deck operations) Shakedown was an excellent opportunity for multiple members of the OSU MTG to help with ship system testing as well as new technicians to get acquainted with the instrumentation and procedures on the HEALY. This was a time to test all the instrumentation on board without the mission critical need to have everything working.
 -Hly_Xsit/Seattle to Kodiak (Support for shipboard underway instrumentations, CTD, ADCP, Echosounders, XBT, deck operations). Final instrumentation testing and configuration will be done during this transit. This will also give the OSU MTG a good opportunity to work and update the systems on the vessel without the requirement of ensuring first class data. 
-Hly1502/Geotraces/Dutch Harbor to Dutch Harbor (Support for shipboard underway instrumentations, CTD ADCP, Echosounders, AutoSal Salinometer, deck operations). Two OSU MTG technicians were on board to maintain and operated the CTD system as well as all the under way sensor systems. 
-HlyXsit/ Dutch Harbor to Juneau (Support for shipboard underway instrumentations, CTD ADCP, Echosounders, AutoSal Salinometer). One OSU MTG was on board to maintain all the underway systems during the transit. 
-HlyXsit/ Juneau to Seattle (Support for shipboard underway instrumentations, CTD ADCP, Echosounders, AutoSal Salinometer). One OSU MTG was on board to maintain all the underway systems during the transit.
In addition to the standard cruise support the OSU MTG helped with numerous trips to the HEALY in Seattle to facilitate instrument maintenance and repair as well as the ship upgrades. The group was involved with all of the vessel maintenance planning as well as all the pre-cruise planning. 


USCG ODEN:


-ODEN/Mix Petermmann Glacier 2015/ Thule Greenland to Kangerslussuaq, Greenland (Support for full process coring operations, Bear guard for day land teams, cruise logistics, deck operations). STARC supported the Geological coring facility for the Mix Petermann Glacier work. This included the full piston gravity core, Multicore and Kasten core support and preservation. A STARC tech in conjunction with the coring support will act as bear guard for the day team for geological shore sampling. 
The Marine Technician Superintendent as the STARC representative from OSU MTG helped with coordination of all aspects of this project. This included the help with permitting, logistics, training, shipping and cruise support. 


Outcome Summary:
The development and improvement of data collection systems and infrastructure is essential to advancing the knowledge and understanding of biological, chemical, physical, geophysical and atmospheric oceanographic research. The technical merit of described activities is demonstrated by the consistently high level of services provided, as evidenced by feedback from Cruise Debriefs and analysis of the data quality by the research community. Our expertise in integrating off-the-shelf and in house designed technologies with existing equipment, and the use of these technologies in novel ways enables us to shorten development cycles, speed the use of innovative approaches to solve problems, and reduce costs.  Knowledge and expertise are shared widely within the UNOLS RVTEC community, as well as with research groups at OSU/SIO and other national and international institutions.
